title: About
text:
üî¨ The Academic and Professional (The Head)
üåü Current Role & Mission
I am Sun Jiahong (Ryan), a Postdoctoral Researcher specializing in Bioinformatics and Computational Biology at The Hong Kong Polytechnic University (PolyU) and Center for Eye and Vision Research (CEVR). My work centers on developing new algorithms for calling genetic variants and studying cancer evolution at single-cell level. I am also interested in a very new research field: AI virtual cell. I aim to translate complex biological datasets into actionable insights, particularly focusing on virtual cell modeling and disease mechanism discovery.
üß¨ Research Focus & Expertise

Omics Data Analysis: Expertise in WGS, single-cell DNA-seq, bulk RNA-seq and single-cell RNA-seq (scRNA-seq) data processing.
Statistical Modeling: Advanced knowledge of Bayesian statistics, machine learning (supervised/unsupervised), and dimensionality reduction techniques.
Computational Tools: Fluent in R (Tidyverse, Bioconductor) and Python (scikit-learn, PyTorch), with experience in cloud computing environments (AWS/GCP).
Key Interest: Currently focused on studying genetic variations in cancers to find common cancer evolutionary patterns and risking factors.

üöÄ What You‚Äôll Find Here
The bioinformatics section of this blog serves as a digital notebook for reproducible research. I share comprehensive tutorials, deep dives into statistical methods, and critiques of new tools. You‚Äôll find code and analysis for challenging projects related to omics data and AI virtual cell models.

title: 20251208-How to build a website on Github
text:
About three years ago, I built a blog website on Github using jekyll, now I want to re-start, so I asked Gemini 3 to help me. I followed its instructions and successfully built it.

1. Archive previous site

Go to your existing repository on GitHub.
Click Settings -> General.
Rename the repository to something like blog-archive-jekyll.
Create a new repository named sunjh22.github.io.



2. Create new repository

Create a new repository named sunjh22.github.io.
Initialize it with a README.md.
Go to Settings > Pages and set the ‚ÄúSource‚Äù to Deploy from a branch -> main -> /docs. (We will configure Quarto to render to a /docs folder).



3. Download and install Quarto
wget https://github.com/quarto-dev/quarto-cli/releases/download/v1.8.26/quarto-1.8.26-linux-amd64.tar.gz
tar -xzf quarto-1.8.26-linux-amd64.tar.gz
ln -s /home/sunjh/data/biosoft/quarto-1.8.26/bin/quarto ~/data/bin/


4. Initialize the Project
git clone https://github.com/sunjh22/sunjh22.github.io.git
cd sunjh22.github.io
quarto create-project myblog --type website:blog
mv myblog/* .
mv myblog/.gitignore .
rmdir myblog


5. Configure for GitHub Pages
Edit _quarto.yml, index.qmd and about.qmd. All the new posts should be under ‚Äòposts/‚Äô directory, make three sub-directories ‚Äòposts/bioinfo‚Äô, ‚Äòposts/life‚Äô and ‚Äòposts/daily‚Äô.


6. Preview and Publish
# Because the port restriction, preview function is not available now.
quarto preview

# Render the full site
quarto render

# Push to Github
git add .
git commit -m "Initial commit"
git push origin main


Bonus for git push

Check for existing SSH keys:

ls -al ~/.ssh
If you see id_ed25519.pub or id_rsa.pub, skip to step 3.

Generate a new SSH key:

ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -C "your_email@example.com"
(Press Enter through all prompts to accept defaults).

Add the key to GitHub: Display your public key:

cat ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub
# Or cat ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub
Copy the output (starts with ssh-ed25519‚Ä¶). Go to GitHub Settings ‚Üí SSH and GPG keys ‚Üí New SSH key. Paste the key and save.

Switch your repository to use SSH: Currently, your repo is looking for the HTTPS link. You need to point it to the SSH link.

# Change remote URL from HTTPS to SSH
git remote set-url origin git@github.com:sunjh22/sunjh22.github.io.git

# Verify it changed
git remote -v
# Should show: origin  git@github.com:sunjh22/sunjh22.github.io.git (fetch)

Push:

git push origin main

title: 20251209-ATAC-seq v.s ChIP-seq
text:
ATAC-seq is used to find genomewide open regions that any protein could bind, including transcription binding site, promoters and enhancers (non-specific). Use hyperactive Tn5 transposase on unfixed nuclei, typically requires 500-50,000 cells as input, it is simple and fast.
ChIP-seq is used to find the binding site of specific proteins (e.g transcription factors) or screen the specific histone modifications by specific antibodies (specific). Use specific antibody against the protein/modification of interest on crosslinked (fixed) chromatin, typically requires 1-10 million cells, it is more labor-intensive.
As seen in ?@fig-histone, there are six common histone modifications. 
?@fig-antibody shows the current best-practice panel (what most big consortia and top labs use in 2024‚Äì2025) for mapping histone modifications.
